original_reasoning:
Okay, let's see. The task is to complete the C# code where there's a TODO comment. The missing part is adding a body to the POST request.

Looking at the existing code for the GET request, they used AddParameter for a URL segment. But for a POST request, adding a body is different. In RestSharp, there are a few ways to add a body. One common method is using AddJsonBody or AddParameter with the body parameter type.

The POST request is supposed to send some data. Since the example uses a GET with a parameter, maybe the POST should send a JSON body. So the code should add a JSON object. For example, adding a simple object like new { Name = "Example" } as the body.

Wait, in RestSharp, when you want to send a JSON body, you can use AddJsonBody. So the line would be postRequest.AddJsonBody(new { Name = "Example" });. Alternatively, using AddParameter with ParameterType.RequestBody. But AddJsonBody is more straightforward for JSON content.

The comment says "Adding a body to the POST request", so the correct code is probably using AddJsonBody. Let me check. Yes, in RestSharp, when using Method.POST, adding a JSON body with AddJsonBody automatically sets the content type and serializes the object. So the missing line is postRequest.AddJsonBody(new { some object });. What's a simple example? Maybe new { id = "123", value = "test" }, but the actual data might not matter as long as the syntax is correct.

So the line to add would be postRequest.AddJsonBody(new { /* data */ });. The exact data isn't specified, so any valid JSON-serializable object. The simplest might be new { data = "example" }, but since the placeholder is there, perhaps using something like the example from the GET, maybe an id. But the actual content isn't specified, so any example would work. So the correct code is postRequest.AddJsonBody(new { id = "123", name = "example" }); or similar. So replacing the TODO with that line.
